note.p: George Washington Gayles was a Baptist minister and Mississippi Congressman. Born on June 29, 1844 in Wilkinson County, Mississippi, Gayles was enslaved by Emily Haile. Although it was against the law in Mississippi, however, Elizabeth Powell taught him to read and write. During the Civil War, he served in the U.S. Army from 1863 through December 1864.

After the war, Gayles moved to Greenville, Mississippi and was ordained as a Baptist minister in 1867. He formed a new church in Bolivar County called the Kindling Altar Church, and in 1878, he became the pastor of Mout Horeb Missionary Baptst Church in Greenville, where he served until the mid-1910s. He also became active in the Baptist State Missionary Convention and served as its president from 1876 through at least 1887. He created and became the editor for the Baptist Signal journal on behalf of the convention. By 1885, he was a chairman of the Colored Baptist Convention of Mississippi, Louisiana, and Arkansas. He remained a leader in the conventions for most of his adult life.

A member of the Republican party, Gayles began his political career in 1869 as a member of the Board of Police in Bolivar County. The following year, he became the county's Justice of the Peace and served briefly as a supervisor for the district. Gayles served in the Mississippi House of Representatives twice (1872-1873 and 1874-1875), and he served in the Mississippi Senate from 1878 to 1882 and from 1884 to 1886. He was the last Black politician to serve in the Mississippi Senate until 1979.

Gayles did not end in his political career in 1886, but his attempts to enter the national stage proved futile in the face of suppression of the Republican Party in Mississippi. Gayles nevertheless, remained active, serving as a delgate to national and international meetings like the National Afro-American Press Association meeting in 1902 and the international Colored Baptists convention in 1904. In the mid-1910s, he also formed the New Hope First Baptist Church and the General Missionary Progressive Baptist State Convention of Mississippi.
Gayles was married to Matilda Gayles. The pair had at least two children, including one boy and one girl. He died on March 5, 1924.
George BWashington Gayles belonged to the following social groups:
Located in south Alabama, Mobile County was established on December 18, 1812. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: A crime defined as "the intention to do something wrong and esp. to cause injury" by causing "someone or something to die." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An occasion when someone is injured or killed by a bullet shot from a gun." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Alcorn Collection. Arrest warrant from A. W. McCormick, justice of the peace in Mobile County, Alabama, calling for the arrest of Columbus Robinson in the case of the murder of George Lott. (This document is the enclosed warrant mentioned in mdah_786-971-06-10).

div.p: Personally appeared before Me A. W. McCormack as Justice of the Peace in and for Said County Peter Roundtree who deposith and Says that on or about the 30th of November 1870 one Columbus Robinson did with malice aforethought Shoot one George Lott with a Pistol with intent to kill him the Said Geo. Lott. all in the County of Mobile State of Alabama. Affiant therefore a warrant for his arrest.
Subscribed and Sworn to this 1st day December 1870 before me

A. W. McCormick
J. P. M. C.

The State of Alabama
Mobile County
To any lawful officer of the State Complaint on oath having been me, that the offence of Shooting with intent to Kill has been Committed, and accusing George Lott thereof You are hereby Commaned forthwith to arrest him and bring him before Me

A W McCormick
J P M C
Joseph Gomez is authorized to execute this warrant

A. W. McCormick
J P M C

The State of Alabama
VS
George Lott
Columbus Robinson

Sup for State
London Clifton
Geo Washington
